threads.com:
How can you claim that you're fully private and that the software is truly yours when you can't even audit the code?

The Linux kernel has 27.8 million lines of code. SystemD has 1.3 million lines of code as of 2019. This makes it impossible for any individual or community to understand it's behavior fully, and thus voids freedom #1 of the GNU definition of free software. Even if you had Linus Torvalds sitting there explaining how each line of code works, it would take months, if not years to fully confirm that it does everything how it should without any sketchy behavior.

For all you know, your kernel might be a little black box constantly sending your information to three letter agencies and China.
It's physically impossible to audit it. The supposed biggest strength of open-source and no one cares to do anything more than virtue signal about it.

last_replies.com: Nobody has actually proposed a pathway that makes this happen, everyone is just speculating. If you give an AI some agency and it manages to "break out" and replicate itself somehow, then maybe, but we haven't even managed to use AI to generate novel thought yet. How do you expect it to go directly from "thing that predicts a word and somehow makes coherent, logical sentences" to "thing that can out-reason humans so sufficiently that it becomes an existential threat"

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>91800919
There's no such thing as a novel thought. It's just combining two ideas into one. No painter paints a tree without seeing one first. No painter paints a tree on the moon without combing two different things. That's what novel means. AI already does this. It can pattern recognise and it can extrapolate. Thats why it's already beating humans in poker, diplomacy and go. The language models work this way too, all it does is extrapolate from a prompt. It does not work by rearranging known content.

Microsoft already have AI updating models in real time but they aren't releasing them to public access. I don't know if others can do it yet. All they need to do is figure out how to infuse an instinct for self preservation.

(defvar *hidden-buffers* nil)

(defun skip-buffer-p (window buffer bury-or-kill)
  (cl-find (buffer-name buffer) *hidden-buffers* :test #'string=))
(customize-set-variable 'switch-to-prev-buffer-skip #'skip-buffer-p)

(defun hide-buffer ()
  (interactive)
  (cl-pushnew (buffer-name) *hidden-buffers* :test #'string=))

or if you are using emacs 29+ you can add the buffer name to switch-to-prev-buffer-skip-regexp

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>91793181
The most important thing is knowing if you need a condenser mic or dynamic mic.

Condenser mic (like you posted in OP, or the Rode NT1-A):
>will capture every little sound you make
>will capture every ambient noise
>you have to be in a dead silent room to get a good result
>must be handled with care (they can be fragile)
>need phantom power for your audio interface
>also need a pop filter
>typically used to record fine performances (singing, etc.) where nuance is important

Dynamic mic (like the Shure SM7B):
>industry standard in radio broadcasting, podcasting, etc.
>will not capture much ambient noise
>probably won't even record properly if you talk a bit too far away or too softly
>will sound great if you talk loudly and confidently near this kind of mic
>absolutely needed if there's going to be noise around you
>not fragile (can be handled somewhat roughly)
>you may need a FetHead or a Cloudlifter with certain mics like the SM7B to boost the gain (it will record at a very quiet level otherwise)
>setup can become quite expensive and needs some experimenting to get the right sound

Also remember you'll have to treat your voice after recording it with any mic, typically by applying compression and a noise gate to make it sound proper.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>91800827
>you have to be in a dead silent room to get a good result
>also need a pop filter
These are not both true at once. Either you have it close, and you need a pop filter, or you have it further away, which means you have to turn up the gain, which also turns up the room noises. Dynamic mics don't magically filter out room noises, they're just less sensitive so you're forced to use them close.

The most obvious conclusion from all of this is that people can argue all they want about what's best and the wonderful truth is that right now the CPU market is very competitive and many of the current options (13600K, 7950X3D, 13900K, 7600 non-x, 13100f, imminent 7800X3D) are extremely good value propositions and there are MASSIVE generational improvements; however, in amongst that greatness there is going to be a single clear and undeniable loser and that is the 7900X3D.

The 7900X3D is going to absolutely suck complete ass in every category. Worse performance than the 7900X-non-3D in production workloads and worse than the 7800X3D in all gaming scenarios, while being significantly more expensive than either. The 7950X3d can at least disable the no 3DVCache CCD and still be an 8 core gaming monster, but the 7900X3d will only have 6 core CCDs and it will be binned worse than the 7800X3D. There is literally no reason for the 7900X3d to exist and AMD knows it; hence their complete refusal to allow pre-release reviews or even send out review samples at all. The 7800 and 7950 X3Ds are some of the best CPUs right now, but the middle child may be the worse in several years.

Even Wayland sessions that “work” look uncanny and unnatural to a seasoned sysadmin. Your bizarre render loop is a dead giveaway. And even if you manage to get a drunk Arch user home with you, he’ll turn tail and bolt the second he gets a whiff of your high latency due to forced VSync.

You will never be happy. You wrench out a fake smile every single morning and tell yourself it’s going to be ok, but deep inside you feel the technical debt creeping up like a weed, ready to crush you under the unbearable weight.

Eventually it’ll be too much to bear - you’ll log into the GitLab instance, select the project, press Delete, and plunge it into the cold abyss. Your users will find the deletion notice, heartbroken but relieved that they no longer have to live with the unbearable shame and disappointment. They’ll remember you as the biggest failure of open source development, and every passerby for the rest of eternity will know a badly run project has failed there. Your code will decay and go to historical archives, and all that will remain of your legacy is a codebase that is unmistakably poorly written.

This is your fate. This is what you chose. There is no turning back.

>>91799809
>Flexibility should include the ability to run all kinds of programs. Lacking the industry standard programs is one of the main reasons why people don't use Linux.
Compatibility is indeed a reason to not use an operating system, but that has nothing to do with how flexible the OS is. Linux's flexibility is the exact reason why it can run on your watch and a super computer using the same exact kernel. Right now, open source operating systems are also the only operating systems that allow you to switch between entirely different desktop implementations. The best you can do elsewhere is emulate this by trying to patch new desktop experiences on, but that sucks. It's really nice being able to have a proper tiling WM, for example, or choose a lightweight DE like XFCE for an older machine, while still being able to use modern software and kernels.
>It also means that video editors for Linux lag behind even more.
Actually, DaVinci Resolve does in fact support HDR workflows on Linux, but it requires going through Decklink for it. Still, they have a complete offering, if someone wanted a complete Linux non-linear video editing workstation for some reason.

The main reason I use it is because its free and I don't want to pay a couple grand for IDA, especially because an IDA license only gives you a decompiler for that particular target architecture. That is seriously limiting and I'm not going to spend that kind of money on a hobby.

The decompiler of ghidra is servicable, but I notice that it is not as clever as IDA. It doesn't take into account all side effects in the decompilation so it requires manual checking. But for that money I take it.

Assuming a fixed battery capacity and a task of rendering a video (as in, exporting in a movie editor, not displaying on screen), what processor offers the most performance per battery watt-hour consumed? Windows 11-compatible processors only, no Raspberry Pi, Apple, mobile, etc. processors.

Long story short, I'm trying to determine the most powerful computer possible that also maintains a long battery life without getting a huge bulky formfactor that's not easy to move around. Most gaming/workstation laptops deplete a battery in like 30 minutes, so discrete graphics cards are out. I bought a Celeron craptop for cheap and I love how light and portable it is, but there must be something out there that offers nearly the same battery sipping but can do a better job with games, video rendering, and 3D CAD (the Celeron does better than I'd ever thought, but I'm sure a premium processor can beat it with similar power draw).

I've tried searching, but battery life tests are always centered around things like casual web browsing or Office, not games, video rendering, or 3D CAD. I already have a powerful laptop for those things, but once again, I'm going for long battery life while doing those things, not just outright power with enough battery to act as a UPS and not much else.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>91786983
The command echo "sn!eed!feed!.s!eed!.g!0+nf+!0nou" | tr "!-z" " -y" | cowsay can be broken down into three parts:

echo "sn!eed!feed!.s!eed!.g!0+nf+!0nou" - This is a command that prints out the string "sn!eed!feed!.s!eed!.g!0+nf+!0nou" to the console.

tr "!-z" " -y" - This is a command that translates characters from one set to another. In this case, it replaces all characters from "!" to "z" with a space character and all characters from "-" to "y" with a "!" character. So the original string "sn!eed!feed!.s!eed!.g!0+nf+!0nou" is transformed into "snee!feed! !s!eed! !g!!!nf!!!nou".

cowsay - This is a command that takes input from the previous command (which in this case is the translated string) and formats it to be displayed in the shape of a cow speaking. The output of this command looks something like this:
 ___________
< snee!feed! >
<  !s!eed!   >
<   g!!!nf!!!nou >
 -----------
        \   ^__^
         \  (oo)\_______
            (__)\       )\/\
                ||----w |
                ||     ||



So the complete command takes the original string "sn!eed!feed!.s!eed!.g!0+nf+!0nou", translates it to "snee!feed! !s!eed! !g!!!nf!!!nou", and then uses the cowsay command to display the translated string in the shape of a cow speaking.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>91798700
The larger the pool of SRAM the higher its latency will be.
There are other practical downsides in terms of die area and heat density, but you almost never run into these with the exception of L3s on modern high perf chips. Advanced 2.5D and 3D packaging alleviates the die area issue though.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>91798700
No, but EPYCs are server CPUs so they're not optimal for the average desktop user.
Higher their higher cache size and core count tend to come at the cost of per core performance, as well as the cost of the CPU and the board to support it.
They're excellent if you're building a compile rig, a multi-role home server, want to have a VM host to test out application in different virtual environments, etc., but I wouldn't recommend using one for a desktop.

You will never be a real display server. You have no hardware cursors, you have no xrandr, you have no setxkbmap. You are a toy project twisted by Red Hat and GNOME into a crude mockery of X11’s perfection.

All the “validation” you get is two-faced and half-hearted. Behind your back people mock you. Your developers are disgusted and ashamed of you, your “users” laugh at your lack of features behind closed doors.

Linux users are utterly repulsed by you. Thousands of years of evolution have allowed them to sniff out defective software with incredible efficiency. Even Wayland sessions that “work” look uncanny and unnatural to a seasoned sysadmin. Your bizarre render loop is a dead giveaway. And even if you manage to get a drunk Arch user home with you, he’ll turn tail and bolt the second he gets a whiff of your high latency due to forced VSync.

You will never be happy. You wrench out a fake smile every single morning and tell yourself it’s going to be ok, but deep inside you feel the technical debt creeping up like a weed, ready to crush you under the unbearable weight.

Eventually it’ll be too much to bear - you’ll log into the GitLab instance, select the project, press Delete, and plunge it into the cold abyss. Your users will find the deletion notice, heartbroken but relieved that they no longer have to live with the unbearable shame and disappointment. They’ll remember you as the biggest failure of open source development, and every passerby for the rest of eternity will know a badly run project has failed there. Your code will decay and go to historical archives, and all that will remain of your legacy is a codebase that is unmistakably poorly written.

This is your fate. This is what you chose. There is no turning back.

It's asynchronous in the sense that transactions are executed statement-by-statement and are rolled back and restarted if there is a conflict due to concurrent access, and the application can drive this process itself. Shopping for NICs for my server-turned-router (which does look like it might just work right out of the box with no issues, at least according to the pfsense documentation I found), trying to figure out what the best combination of NICs to get is.

The motherboard has 1 built in 2.5 gig NIC, and an E-key WiFi module that I will be removing. I have two spare PCIe 3.0 x1 slots, and one spare PCIe 4.0 x8 slot (x16 physical) that I really don't want to use for ethernet unless I have to. I need to end up with 2x 1 gig NICs for external traffic, and at least 2x 2.5 gig NICs for internal -- but if I can get extra on either I would appreciate it.

What seems to be the best option is:
- an m.2 E-key single 2.5 gig NIC (e.g. https://www.amazon.com/KVSERT-Ethernet-RTL8125B-Industrial-Control/dp/B0BSH4B8ZK/ )
- a PCIe x1 slot double 1 gig NIC (e.g. https://www.amazon.com/Gigabit-Ethernet-Converged-Network-Chipset/dp/B0B28CGP2B )

However... I do notice that there are a very small number of m.2 E-key double 1gig NICs, and exactly one PCIe x1 slot double 2.5 gig NIC... and that would put me significantly an extra 2.5gig NIC ahead. Is it worth risking what may be less reliable hardware for an extra 2.5gig? I'm not sure I trust these m.2 NICs, so having my intake occur across one has me a bit worried. At least with the other setup if the m.2 NIC fails I still have one 2.5gig NIC from the motherboard connected to the LAN and the server doesn't go dark.

- m.2 E-kay double 1 gig NIC ( https://www.amazon.com/HINYSENO-Ethernet-Interface-Controller-HS-ME8111A-2BT/dp/B0B1VB6QTJ )
- PCIe x1 slot double 2.5 gig NIC ( https://www.amazon.com/Dual-Port-2-5GBase-T-RTL8125B-Ethernet-Controller/dp/B0B4V6MPHD )

>To advance my research further, I need to understand how to change a computer program into SKI combinators.
I had a glance at the Wikipedia article for SKI combinators. The "Boolean logic" heading in the "SKI expressions" section describes how to implement Boolean functions like AND, OR, NOT, etc. using SKI expressions.

So what I think you need to do to convert a program into SKI expressions, is you first need to somehow turn your program into a Boolean expression, and then you can convert that into an SKI expression by using the SKI definitions for those Boolean functions.

So the question is how to turn a program into a Boolean expression?
The appropriate search term here is "how to convert a program into a Boolean circuit". I found this result: https://cs.stackexchange.com/a/102236
Someone on Stack Exchange says you can use something called CBMC to translate a program into a SAT formula, which I'm pretty sure is the same thing as a Boolean circuit/Boolean expression. The bad news is that it doesn't seem possible to do this with programs that have infinite loops, etc. but I think it might still suit your needs? Please look into this and maybe into other search results, you could find something suitable.

It was interesting reading about this Maid-anon. SKI expressions is a fascinating concept
